laws.lawDescription: The Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA) is a federal law that reauthorized the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA). It aims to provide all students with a fair and equitable education by setting high standards, supporting effective teaching, and ensuring accountability in schools. ESSA emphasizes state and local flexibility in designing educational systems and includes provisions for assessments, accountability, school improvement, and support for disadvantaged students.

The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) is a federal law that ensures students with disabilities receive a free and appropriate public education (FAPE) tailored to their unique needs. IDEA requires schools to provide special education and related services to eligible students, including individualized education programs (IEPs), early intervention services, and transition services for students preparing for post-secondary education or employment.

laws.lawName: Title IX of the Education Amendments Act
laws.lawDescription: Title IX of the Education Amendments Act is a federal law that prohibits sex-based discrimination in educational institutions receiving federal funding. It covers various areas, including admissions, athletics, sexual harassment, and gender-based violence. Title IX aims to ensure equal educational opportunities and foster safe and inclusive learning environments for all students.

laws.lawName: Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)
laws.lawDescription: The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) is a federal law that protects the privacy of student education records. FERPA grants parents and eligible students the right to access and control their educational records, while also imposing restrictions on the disclosure of personally identifiable information. FERPA helps safeguard student privacy and provides guidelines for educational institutions in handling and sharing student records.

The No Child Left Behind Act (NCLB) was a federal law that aimed to improve educational outcomes and accountability in schools. It required states to set academic standards, implement assessments, and establish adequate yearly progress (AYP) goals. NCLB emphasized closing achievement gaps, providing options for students in low-performing schools, and ensuring highly qualified teachers. It was replaced by the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA) in 2015.

laws.lawName: Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act
laws.lawDescription: The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act (Perkins Act) is a federal law that supports career and technical education (CTE) programs. It provides funding for the development and improvement of CTE programs that prepare students for post-secondary education and careers. The Perkins Act emphasizes partnerships between educational institutions, business, and industry to align CTE programs with workforce needs and promote student success in high-demand fields.

The Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA) is a federal law that provides federal funding to support K-12 education. ESEA aims to address educational inequalities and improve educational opportunities for disadvantaged students. It includes provisions for federal programs such as Title I, which provides funding for schools with high concentrations of low-income students. ESEA has been reauthorized multiple times, with the most recent reauthorization being the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA).

The Higher Education Act (HEA) is a federal law that governs federal student financial aid programs and supports higher education institutions. HEA provides funding for student grants, loans, and work-study programs, and it establishes guidelines and regulations for accreditation, student loan programs, and institutional accountability. HEA aims to make higher education accessible and affordable for students and promotes educational opportunities and resources.

The Equal Educational Opportunities Act (EEOA) is a federal law that prohibits discrimination based on race, color, national origin, sex, or language proficiency in public schools. It requires schools to take action to overcome language barriers that impede equal participation in educational programs. EEOA promotes equal access to quality education for all students, regardless of their background or language abilities.

The McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act is a federal law that provides support and protections for homeless children and youth. It ensures their access to free, appropriate public education and removes barriers that may hinder their enrollment, attendance, and success in school. The law requires schools to identify and provide necessary services to homeless students, including transportation, school supplies, and referrals to community resources.

laws.lawName: National School Lunch Program The National School Lunch Program (NSLP)
laws.lawDescription: Child Nutrition Programs, including the National School Lunch Program (NSLP) and the School Breakfast Program (SBP), are federal laws that aim to improve children's access to nutritious meals in school. These programs provide eligible students with free or reduced-price meals, ensuring they receive adequate nutrition for their academic success and overall well-being. Child Nutrition Programs prioritize providing meals to students from low-income families.

The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) is a federal law that prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities. ADA ensures equal access to public accommodations, including educational institutions. It requires schools to provide reasonable accommodations and support services to students with disabilities, allowing them to participate fully in educational programs and activities.

laws.lawName: Child Care and Development Block Grant (CCDBG) Act
laws.lawDescription: The Child Care and Development Block Grant (CCDBG) Act is a federal law that provides funding to states for child care assistance programs. CCDBG aims to improve the affordability, quality, and accessibility of child care services. The law sets health and safety standards for child care providers and offers support to low-income families, ensuring access to quality child care while parents work or pursue education.

The National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) is a federal program that assesses and monitors the educational achievement of students in the United States. NAEP provides data on student performance in various subjects and allows for comparisons between states and demographic groups. The program helps inform education policy and provides valuable insights into the effectiveness of educational systems.

laws.lawName: Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act (SDFSCA)
laws.lawDescription: The Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act (SDFSCA) was a federal law that aimed to promote safe and drug-free learning environments in schools. It supported prevention programs, intervention initiatives, and community partnerships to address issues such as substance abuse, violence, and bullying. SDFSCA emphasized the importance of comprehensive approaches to student well-being and academic success.

The Head Start Act is a federal law that provides comprehensive early childhood education, health, nutrition, and parent involvement services to low-income children and families. Head Start programs focus on preparing children for school readiness and supporting their overall development. The law promotes positive outcomes for children and offers support to families in need.

laws.lawName: English Language Acquisition Act (Title III of ESEA)
laws.lawDescription: The English Language Acquisition Act, also known as Title III of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA), provides federal funding to support English language learners (ELLs) in acquiring English proficiency and achieving academic success. The law promotes effective language instruction, professional development for educators, and the development of high-quality language programs and assessments for ELLs.

The Investing in Innovation (i3) Program is a federal initiative that provides grants to support innovative approaches and practices in education. i3 aims to improve student achievement, close achievement gaps, and enhance the effectiveness of education systems. The program funds projects that demonstrate strong evidence of effectiveness and have the potential for replication and scaling.

The Race to the Top (RTTT) Program was a federal competitive grant program that encouraged education reforms and innovations at the state level. RTTT focused on four key areas: adopting rigorous standards and assessments, attracting and retaining effective educators, using data to inform instruction and decision-making, and turning around low-performing schools. The program aimed to improve student outcomes and promote systemic change in education.

The Alabama Education Accountability Act is a state law that establishes a comprehensive system for measuring and improving the performance of schools and districts. It sets academic standards, implements assessments, and holds schools accountable for student achievement. The law aims to ensure that all students in Alabama receive a quality education.

laws.lawName: Alabama Math, Science, and Technology Initiative
laws.lawDescription: The Alabama Math, Science, and Technology Initiative (AMSTI) is a state initiative that promotes improved instruction and student achievement in the areas of math, science, and technology. AMSTI provides professional development for educators, instructional resources, and support for the implementation of rigorous standards. The initiative aims to enhance STEM education in Alabama schools.

The Alabama Reading Initiative (ARI) is a state program that focuses on improving reading instruction and literacy skills for students in Alabama. ARI provides training and resources for educators, promotes research-based reading strategies, and supports the implementation of effective reading programs. The initiative aims to ensure that all students in Alabama become proficient readers.

Alaska's Education Challenge is a state initiative that seeks to improve educational outcomes and opportunities for all students in Alaska. It focuses on three core priorities: increasing student success, supporting responsible and reflective learners, and cultivating safety and well-being. The initiative aims to address the unique challenges and needs of Alaska's diverse student population.

The Alaska Measures of Progress (AMP) is the state assessment program that measures student achievement in various subjects. AMP provides data on student performance and helps inform instructional practices and educational decision-making. The program aims to assess student learning and support improvement efforts in Alaska's schools and districts.

Arizona's Move On When Reading is a state law that focuses on improving early literacy skills and ensuring that students are reading proficiently by the end of third grade. The law provides support and interventions for struggling readers, requires additional reading instruction for students who are not meeting proficiency standards, and emphasizes the importance of early intervention and targeted literacy programs.

laws.lawName: Arizona College and Career Ready Standards
laws.lawDescription: The Arizona College and Career Ready Standards (AZCCRS) are state academic standards that outline the knowledge and skills students should master at each grade level. AZCCRS provide a clear set of expectations for student learning and achievement, preparing them for success in college, careers, and life. The standards cover English language arts, mathematics, science, and social studies.

The Arkansas Accountability System is a state program that measures and reports the performance of schools and districts. It sets standards, assesses student achievement, and holds schools accountable for improvement. The program aims to ensure high-quality education for all students in Arkansas.

laws.lawName: Arkansas Better Chance for School Success
laws.lawDescription: The Arkansas Better Chance for School Success (ABC) program is a state-funded pre-kindergarten program that provides early childhood education opportunities to eligible children. ABC focuses on school readiness and aims to enhance the cognitive, social, and emotional development of participating children.

laws.lawName: California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress
laws.lawDescription: The California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress (CAASPP) is the state's comprehensive assessment program. It measures student achievement in English language arts, mathematics, science, and other subjects. CAASPP provides valuable data to inform teaching and learning and supports the continuous improvement of California's education system.

The California Common Core State Standards (CCSS) are state academic standards that specify the knowledge and skills students should acquire at each grade level. CCSS provide a consistent framework for instruction and assessment, ensuring students are prepared for college and career success.

The Colorado Measures of Academic Success (CMAS) is the state's assessment program that measures student proficiency in various subjects. CMAS provides data to evaluate student learning, inform instruction, and support educational improvement efforts in Colorado schools and districts.

The Colorado Academic Standards define what students should know and be able to do in each grade and subject. These standards guide curriculum development, instruction, and assessment, promoting high-quality education and preparing students for post-secondary success.

The Connecticut Mastery Examination Program is a state assessment program that measures student achievement in various subjects. It provides data to evaluate student performance, inform instructional practices, and support educational decision-making.

The Connecticut Core Standards (CCS) are state academic standards that define the knowledge and skills students should master at each grade level. CCS provide a foundation for high-quality education and prepare students for college, careers, and civic engagement.
